In your next partisan screed—instead of focusing so much on me and how terrible I am—maybe you should respond to Mr Jorss, who is an investor and has built amazing businesses in the coal industry. Respond to him and say why he is wrong. Mr Jorss goes on to say:
Global coal demand is at the highest level in history—
he's right about that—

and it's fanciful to think that reducing our high-quality exports in the face of record demand will do anything other than drive up energy and steel prices, create a net increase in global emissions and destroy Australian jobs, both in regions and in cities.

Mr Jorss doesn't sound too supportive of the government's measures. Apparently, Minister Watt wants to mislead the Senate because he does not recognise the comments there of Mr Jorss. I'll move on. New Hope Group, another business that has been totally screwed over by Labor government's for many years, finally got their project approval after 12 years. The Australian article says:

New Hope Group chief executive Rob Bishop said the amendments were built on "a political objective on a base demonisation of fossil fuels" and that they would see Australia abandon its role as a reliable energy exporter for the region.
That is more criticism from the coal industry that Minister Watt has failed to address in any of his contributions. The article continues:

President of Peabody's Australian operations, Jamie Frankcombe, said the company was concerned the legislation would "make the mining industry less competitive at a time when it's integral to providing the minerals and energy required for the energy transition".
Where's the support here? There's no support. Mr Frankcombe goes on to say:

The very real danger in setting aspirational emission reduction targets and imposing rigid rules to achieve them is that it will reduce our cost competitiveness, lead to potential job losses and hurt regional communities.
Those are the communities, Minister Watt, that you fly in and fly out of. You don't actually live there. The article further states:
A spokesman for Glencore said the reforms needed to achieve emissions reductions without "destroying the jobs and investments that are critical to the national economy".
It goes on and on. There are more comments from the gas industry too, which I'll perhaps get to later this evening.

Before I get to some more detailed questions, I want to put into context what we're doing. I touched on this in my second reading debate contribution, but I want to make a comparison. We're putting all these costs and risks on the coal industry and other industries, whose concerns have been outlined in the article I've quoted. In terms of the benefit that we are going to get from this bill, according to the government's own target set out in their position paper on the safeguard mechanism, this will reduce carbon emissions by 205 million tonnes. That's the reduction they'll achieve. That sound like a lot, but a couple of weeks ago on 13 March this year, the Biden administration approved the Willow project in Alaska, which will produce 180,000 barrels of oil a day. That one project is going to produce a total of 263 million tonnes of emissions. So we've spent all this time here this week—and we're going to be here until God knows what hour again tonight—lauding ourselves and saying how fantastic we are because the tides are not rising anymore, the temperature is falling and we can already feel it get colder. Apparently we're shifting the world here in this little room. And, after all this effort and with all of the uncertainty we'll impose on the major industries that bankroll our nation, all we're going to do is reduce our emissions by 205 million times. Meanwhile, one decision of the so-called climate-conscious Democratic elected Biden administration, 263 million tonnes from that one decision in Alaska, completely blows out of the water everything we've done and more. ConocoPhillips, who are the proponents of the Willow project, used to invest in Australia, too. They largely don't anymore; they sold out of Darwin, unfortunately, so we've lost them. ConocoPhillips released to the stock exchange in New York that they welcomed the decision from Houston.

You know what? In their whole media release announcing the Willow project there was not a single mention of carbon emissions. No mention of offsetting them or going to net zero—not a single mention. Do you know what they did mention, though, which again Minister Watt failed to mention his contribution at all? This is what ConocoPhillips said: 'The Willow project fits within the Biden administration's priority of environmental and social justice, facilitating the energy transition and enhancing our energy security all while creating good union jobs.'

Good union jobs—that's what the coal industry provides. I back those unions and I stand with the CFMMEU supporting the industry. These guys don't ever mention it. Where is the mention of the union jobs here that you're going to destroy through these policies? Because if you don't, if we have the reaction we've seen from the coal industry and we don't get the investment, we're not going to get those good union jobs. They'll go to Alaska and the Middle East and China and Russia, and they won't be here in this country anymore. So I don't care how much you criticise me. I will keep fighting for those good union jobs, because you are not.

Senator COX (Western Australia) (20:21): I foreshadow that I will move amendments on sheet 1920 standing in my name when my time comes, but I want to take the opportunity to outline those amendments now. As the legislation currently stands this very broad power under section 33 of the Industry Research and Development Act gives various ministers the power to make grants on wide grounds. So long as they are within the legislative power of the Commonwealth they can throw as much money as they want at it. This provision was the pipeline that the Morrison government used to throw cash at its gas fired recovery, but this amendment, which I understand has the support of the Senate, will turn that tap off.

Money for the purposes of subsidising coal and gas construction will now be prohibited. This is one less pool of money that the fossil fuel industry can dip their greedy little hands into. The previous government actually gave money through this provision to hand $50 million to frack the Beetaloo Basin against the wishes of traditional owners. Gas companies that made donations to the Liberals and flew together in private jets—I wonder if Senator McKenzie was part of that jaunt—with former Minister Taylor received public money under this provision. Empire Energy received $19 million and Tamboran received $7.5 million. But today it's my great pleasure to announce to the chamber that since the announcement of the package that the Greens negotiated with the government on Monday the stock value of Tamboran and has fallen by 15 per cent and Empire Energy stocks have fallen by 22 per cent. How about that! This section 33 power was also used to bankroll—
Senator McKenzie interjecting—

Sena
tor COX: Listen carefully, Senator McKenzie: it was used to bankroll the new coal fired power plant in Collinsville and to fund coal and gas plants in the Underwriting New Generation Investment. With the support of this change this amendment will close down such horrid ways of using public money in the future. We say thank you.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:23): Minister, I'm sure you've probably answered this question, but unfortunately I've been at other events—what modelling has the government done and what assurances can the government provide of what the impact of these reforms will be on the economy? Can you guarantee that facilities will be able to meet the requirements and no facilities will be forced to shut down or jobs lost as a result of the decisions the Senate will make tonight thanks to the government's deal with the Greens?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:24): I have answered questions about this matter from Senator Duniam, Senator Hughes and Senator McDonald. I don't have anything further to add to the information I have already provided to the Senate.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:24): Have you provided information to the Senate about the number of jobs lost as a result of this decision? Minister, I think there's some advice being provided to you by the department.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Sterle ): Senator McKenzie, I was giving the minister an opportunity to get that advice; then I'll give her the call. I see Senator Steele-John has his hand up as well. We are waiting for the minister. The minister has nothing to add. Senator Steele-John?

Senator ST
EELE-JOHN (Western Australia) (20:25): My question to the minister is this: I would like the minister to be able to provide the chamber with the number of times Woodside Energy group were consulted during the crafting of the original piece of legislation. As a preamble to my question, I want to state clearly for the record and draw the Senate's attention to the reality that, right now, global temperatures are rising, and have risen, by about 1.2 degrees above their pre-industrial level, and it is very clear from the work of the world's finest climate scientists that, with every decade that goes past and every year that goes past, those temperatures continue to rise.

The Paris Agreement goal, adopted just eight years ago in 2015, was to limit the global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century. We are already, as I say, at 1.2 degrees Celsius and on track for another 0.2 degrees of warming as we go through this decade. The reality that we are faced with now as a species upon this planet is that every single year that passes without meaningful action on climate is a year in which we slip closer to an irretrievable climate disaster. What exactly that will mean in real terms is difficult to comprehend when we are already seeing catastrophic once-in-a-generation climate events unfolding with an alarming regularity.

These dire straits are reflected in the final part of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's sixth annual report, released last week. This is the world's official body for the assessment of climate change telling us in the clearest possible terms, and not for the first time, that we need a rapid, deep, systems-wide emissions reduction program. The time, as they say, is well and truly up. The climate bomb is uncomfortably close to boom time.

An idealistic view—and I say this generously—of the safeguards mechanism bill Labor introduced to the House is that it was an attempt to defuse that bomb. A more realistic view is that this was largely a piece of legislation built on smoke and mirrors—or woodsmoke, more precisely, as we stare down the barrel of another potentially catastrophic La Nina summer this year—because the bill that Labor originally presented to the House was not in fact a climate bill.

By its design it allowed big, cashed-up polluters to continue business as usual. All that they would need to do is find a little bit more cash by making a little bit more money from the next global energy crisis to buy some crappy offsets to offset their big pollution and exceed their allocated level of pollution. By design, Labor's original bill allowed big polluters to offset 100 per cent of their emissions, something many nations economically and ideologically comparable to Australia had made illegal. By design, Labor's original bill allowed big polluters to increase their emissions, as long as their number crunchers were good enough at their jobs to make it look otherwise on paper.

That's right—under the original bill put forward by Labor, national emissions from coal and gas could go up, and were in fact forecast to go up. The government would be able to claim that they had succeeded in reducing national emissions, all thanks to some sly climate accounting. And emissions would of course go up because the bill that the government originally brought to the house backed in new coal and gas development—some 116 in the pipeline in front of the government right now.

Even if, by some stroke of magic, the bill in its original form had actually reduced emissions, any climate gain would have been completely written off by just one new project alone: the Burrup Hub in my home state of Western Australia. What we see in this reality is a community in Western Australia forced to take up the fight against these projects directly, because they know that their government will do nothing more than tinker around the edges on climate policy. One of the members of my team, somebody who I am proud to call a colleague, Joanna Partyka, recently took up this very fight with her brave protest against Woodside as part of the 'Disrupt Burrup Hub' campaign. I want to pay tribute to that courageous activist group this evening. For her climate activism, like many others engaged in similar actions around the country, Jo is being pursued by the police. She had her home raided by the counterterrorism police. This is the dystopian reality that the government has created. The pre-eminent global climate body sounds the alarm for immediate action, and the brave folk responding to that alarm are being criminalised. Meanwhile, the government quietly shuffles the papers around, trying not to draw attention to itself.

This reality has been created because the government—particularly this Labor government, along with its counterpart at the state level—basically functions as a subsidiary of the fossil fuel industry. Their friends, the oil and gas barons, masquerade as members of the WA community, upstanding in their nature, while those in the government play the role of their elected representatives in this place—a thinly veiled front for Woodside, Rio Tinto and Chevron. That's the reality of who the Greens have been negotiating with through the course of this process. That's the reality of who the government is up against in this fight.

The amendments that the Greens have secured ensure that real pollution will actually go down. What a radical idea! It's not just on paper: the introduction of a hard cap on actual emissions, one that will be ratcheted down over time is a welcome step. Also secured by our amendments is the work to rein in dodgy offsets, ensuring that big polluters can't continue to buy their way out of responsibility to abate emissions. As a whole, we believe that our amendments will place a huge financial burden on many of the 116 coal projects in the pipeline under this government, ultimately making it less likely for them to go ahead. But as this legislation, improved as it has been, is considered before the Senate tonight it is the community's right to know how often Woodside was consulted in the crafting of the original piece of legislation. This company treats my state of Western Australia as its playground, has made money from our resources for decades and happily lends a bit of it out here and there to buy social license from the creative industries to put themselves forward as a friend of the community—all the while profiting from the extraction and burning of chemicals and pollutants that ruin our environment. So, Minister, how often were they at the table during the course of the crafting of this legislation?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:34): Senator Steele-John, thank you for your contribution. I actually find it disappointing that you've chosen this evening to minimise what is actually quite an important moment for this parliament. We have had 10 years where the previous government was unable to settle a climate policy and consequently unable to settle an energy policy, and the consequences of that are playing out each and every day for households all over this country and for businesses. They're playing out for the climate too.

You're quite right to call attention to the IPCC report, and you're quite right to point to the fact that this is a critical decade. Actually, the last decade was the critical decade. That was the decade when it would have been good to get on the path to net zero. Regrettably, the government that was in place then chose not to do so. They couldn't land a policy amongst themselves. The Nats bickered with the Libs, and the outer metropolitan Libs bickered with the inner metropolitan Libs, and nothing happened.

It matters a great deal to stabilise climate and energy policy in this country. For the first time, we have a parliament where the stated position of a majority of senators and members is for climate action. We are really proud to have had the opportunity as a government to bring forward meaningful and significant reforms that will put us on a path to net zero, to do the hard work that is necessary to build ambition, to build a global coalition, to deal with this problem which we know can only be tackled by collective global action. That's our responsibility. It's our responsibility as a government, and I would put it to you that it's our responsibility as a parliament.

The shame about the way that you approach your contribution—I'm sorry, I don't wish to scold you, Senator Steele-John, but I do wish you point out our differences in approach. We are grateful for the very constructive engagement we had with your leader and with your party room. We think it's important that people of goodwill can work together across the parliament, and we are genuinely grateful for it. I do wish to acknowledge that. You asked me a question, and I will get to that.

I've spoken on many occasions—some of the people who have been in the chamber for much of this afternoon might be a little bit tired of this explanation. One of the things about stabilising climate policy and establishing an enduring and durable policy solution is working with stakeholders across the board, and we make absolutely no apologies for having met with as many of the participants in the existing safeguard mechanism as possible. It was a long consultation process. From recollection, we announced our policy prior to the election; following the election we published a consultation paper last August and we sought feedback; we released legislation, I think, in December; we published a further detailed paper along with draft rules in January. We have sought to engage deeply with civil society and with business to deeply understand what the implications of this reform would be. I'm not going to provide information about the specifics of who met what when, because the truth is there's been an enormous amount of engagement right across the spectrum. I do think that is a good thing. It's how we should do policy, and I think that we are going to get a good result.

Turning to another matter, I did promise earlier to provide advice to Senator Cash about the approach for lithium hydroxide producers. She asked me very specific question. I can advise the chamber that lithium hydroxide producers who enter the safeguard mechanism from 1 July 2023 will enter as new entrants, and as a consequence they will have new entrant baselines. The value of those baselines will be set through consultation with industry and other stakeholders during 2023.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:39): It's passing strange that tonight, at 8.45, we have seven Greens senators in the chamber happy to debate and take up opposition time—precious opposition time—to ask serious questions of the government about the deal that the Greens and the Labor Party reached on getting the safeguard mechanism through this parliament. Senator Steele-John, as he exits the Senate, takes up—

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Fawcett ): Senator McKenzie, you know it's out of order to refer to someone who's leaving the chamber.

Senator McKENZIE: The seven senators from the Greens party who were not here at nine o'clock last night, who were not here at midnight, who were not here at 3 am—I know many of the Labor Party colleagues across the chamber understand the responsibility as parties of government to actually keep the chamber open, keep the debate open and make sure that the Australian people's variety of views on legislation, no matter what the topic, are able to be expressed in a respectful manner. The Greens political party was not here at 3.30, nor at 4.13 am today, but Labor Party senators were. Liberal and National Party senators were, because we understand how important this chamber is to having a democratic debate about legislation that governments bring before this place.

So for Senator Steele-John to use precious opposition time in the committee phase, which is going to be truncated, to effectively deliver a second reading speech, which he could have done any time last night like the rest of us, it's the lazy approach, the lazy accomplices, I'm going to call them, to the government's agenda. The lazy accomplices are the Greens political party. They drop in when it's convenient, they drop the bomb and they roll on out.

We have so many questions, particularly those of us that are interested in the resources industry and the safeguard mechanism's impact on rural and regional communities, our industries, knowing that of the 215 companies that are going to be impacted by this mechanism, we seriously want to understand, given that 84 per cent of them are in the regions; they are not in Fitzroy or inner-city Brisbane or inner-city Sydney; they are in the communities that we have been sent here to represent, and we are just doing our job by asking the government what the impact would be, given that 84 per cent of the impact would be against employees in our communities.

I would respectfully request that the Greens use the opportunities available to them, to stay up late like the rest of us, fulfil your democratic duties like the rest of us, instead of using up time that could be used to actually ask the questions from not the inner cities, but from the outer suburban and regional communities that are trying to understand the implications and impost of this deal that you have done on their future.

Minister, I understand that modelling has been done by EY. Was EY charged with modelling the impact on each individual sector impacted by the safeguard mechanism? Was this done at an enterprise level? Because surely that will be the only way the government can ascertain the impact on specific geographic regions. And did the government rely on financial data collected at a corporate level to work out the impact on each facility? I appreciate that those three questions will go to the same answer.

Senator Mc
ALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:44): I have canvassed some of these same kinds of questions with Senator McDonald and others. EY was engaged to undertake some modelling work or some analysis—it might be more accurately characterised as that. I believe that that is listed on AusTender. I need to seek advice about what can be said about that. Like much of the work, it was engaged with in the context of a cabinet decision-making process. I'm really not sure what I can say to you at this point in time, and I'm not comfortable providing advice without taking advice.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:45): Minister, are you seeking public interest immunity? This is quite a simple question, and the committee stage in the Senate is for us to actually ascertain what the impact is on our communities. You won the war—away you go—but we need to understand what genuine assessment the government has done to understand the impact of their decision-making on our communities and our industries. I'm very concerned if (a) that wasn't detailed analysis, (b) that didn't go to the facility level, or (c) that didn't actually consult with enterprises themselves. We've all got the list, and we've all got the database—we know the number 215. But what is going to be the impact of that, and did you rely on financial data collected at the corporate level to work out the impact? If the departmental officials in front of you don't have that information available to them, I would find that very concerning, given the potential impact that this legislation will have on our communities.

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:46): I think I've provided an answer. The fact of the analysis and that EY was engaged to do analysis and work is public, as you know. The content of that fed into a decision of government through the cabinet processes, and I'm not at liberty to disclose it to you.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:46): Are you telling the Senate that you don't understand the impact of your legislation on our communities, on our regions and on our industries?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:47): That question doesn't follow from the advice that I've provided to you. It doesn't make sense as a conclusion, and you shouldn't draw such a conclusion from the advice I've provided.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:47): It's actually the only conclusion I can draw, Minister—that you are prepared to stand up in the Australian Senate on an evening when the deal has been done and it's passing, and all we, Senator Canavan, Senator McDonald, Senator Duniam and those of us who have risen throughout the day, are seeking to do is get an intelligent and informed understanding of the impact.
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator McKENZIE: I hear the Greens laughing, but they don't represent Gladstone, Rockhampton or Murrumba. They do not represent the Latrobe Valley. They do not represent the Alcoa—
Honourable senators interjecting—
Senator McKENZIE: I'm sorry, but you don't. They don't vote for you.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Fawcett ): Order! Senator McKenzie, resume your seat. The Greens senators will respect the standing orders and not interject when a senator is on her feet speaking.

Senator McKENZIE: Senator McAllister, unless you are seeking public interest immunity over this information, this is precisely the forum in which we are justified in asking these questions. You are putting this legislation forward. It will become law. Where else do we actually get these answers from? We know EY did the modelling. We want to understand whether you understood that from a facility level, whether you understood it from a geographic-place level and whether you actually understood. You talk about going to cabinet, so was cabinet informed of the impact, at a very local, granular level, of this legislation? If it wasn't, fine. If it was, what is it? You're asking the Senate to make a decision tonight on this legislation, but, without that level of information, you're asking us to do that blindly. You either have to claim public interest immunity or tell us what EY said—or maybe you didn't bother asking.

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:49): I'm sitting here racking my brain, trying to think of an occasion when members from the previous government stood in this spot here in the chamber and shared details about cabinet consideration. I'm trying to think: when did that happen? The answer is: on absolutely no occasion did that happen, because that's not how cabinet government works. Senator McKenzie, I will take on notice your request, but it is entirely usual for cabinet material not to be disclosed.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:50): I appreciate cabinet material, but impact of government decision-making shouldn't be. Has policy impact analysis been conducted on the government's deal with the Greens, noting that only the Prime Minister can exempt a government entity from the need to complete impact analysis and only then in very limited circumstances?

The South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy, with major members such as BHP, Santos and Beach Energy, have said that as part of the last-minute deal between the Albanese government and the Greens that will force new gas projects to be net zero from day 1. Why is the government imposing an immediate net zero obligation on energy sources needed to support the transition?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:50): There were two questions, I think, there. The first was in relation to regulatory impact assessment, and I have answered this question already in response to questions, I think, from Senator McDonald. I don't have anything further to add to that.

The second question related to the arrangements that are proposed to be put in place for some new entrants associated with LNG production. As I've explained on many occasions throughout the debate, the government engaged in an extended period of consultation in preparing the material for the chamber. It began last year and involved many workshops, round tables, meetings, submissions and a Senate hearing, and has been discussed at estimates. It's been a very extended discussion with a very wide range of people, and I think the policy process was the better for it.

In relation to the approach to new gas, I can advise you, Senator McKenzie—and I have discussed this already—that new gas fields supplying existing liquefied natural gas facilities will be treated as new facilities so that they are given international best practice baselines for the carbon dioxide in their new fields. For these new fields' reservoir CO2 emissions best practice is zero, given the existence of low-CO2 fields and opportunities for carbon capture and storage.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:52): The EM states the bill will have no financial impact on the budget other than the remuneration of the reduction assurance committee chair. Why hasn't the cost of requiring ACCUs to implement the price cap been considered, given the government will be required to flood the market with ACCUs if the cap price is reached?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:53): There's an existing budget allocation for the Powering the Regions Fund that may be used for the purchase of ACCUs.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:53): The Greens claim to have secured a pollution trigger in the safeguard mechanism bill. What section of the bill establishes that pollution trigger, how will it work and what assessment has been undertaken to determine the impact on the viability of projects that have already been in the pipeline?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:54): I have already answered this. I was trying to find the piece of paper I relied upon the last time, so that I could provide consistent information to the chamber, but it's set out in the explanatory memorandum. Essentially, the intention of the change is to ensure that the minister, the climate change secretary and the Climate Change Authority have the necessary information about designated large facilities that may increase their scope 1 emissions, or new facilities that may become designated large facilities, and can appropriately monitor the impact of the achievement of the revised object of the NGERs. Essentially, the object of the NGER Act sets out, or will set out, the obligation to reduce emissions. Where the minister for the environment makes an approval that increases the emissions of a covered safeguard facility, a notification obligation arises to the secretary of the department, the Climate Change Authority and the minister. Obligations then attach to the secretary of the department and the Climate Change Authority to assess whether that information suggests that the objects of the act may not be met, and if that is the case they need to advise the minister and the minister needs to put in place a process to assess what steps, if any, need to be taken in response. As I indicated to Senator O'Sullivan, when he asked me this same question, it does not provide the ability for the minister for climate change to cancel or in any way change approval that's been provided under a separate act by a separate minister.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:56): Given the UK government is spending $2 billion each year for the next 20 years to encourage companies to adopt new low-emissions technology, and given the US Biden government is spending even more to help its industries engage in new technology, such as carbon capture, usage and storage, why is Australia's only strategy to engage in a national act of limbo? This is not a technology that your government or the Greens is keen on promoting. This is proven technology that is working on 30 projects around the world, with more than 100 under development, and reducing emissions by 40 million tonnes, or one-tenth of Australia's emissions. Is the Australian government opposed to this technology, which is recognised globally as one of the technologies that will help the globe reduce emissions and get to net zero? This includes nuclear technologies, but I'm not asking about nuclear. Will CCUS technology be available to ports that are exporting Australian product, as is being done in large European ports, such as Rotterdam?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (20:57): The point of this bill is to create material incentives for covered facilities to make investments to reduce their emissions, and it may well be the consequence that people will choose to invest in CCUS.

Senator McKENZIE (Victoria—Leader of the Nationals in the Senate) (20:58): Finally, last night when we were here to the wee hours talking about your recovery fund, Minister Farrell stood here and asked us not to conflate this particular deal with the Greens with the desire to build a manufacturing industry in Australia, which your fund seeks to do. I find it passing strange that, whilst today we are passing legislation that will impact significant employers, particularly in rural and regional Australia, the government has failed, in answering my questions—my apologies if you've answered Senator McDonald, Senator Brockman or Senator Canavan about jobs lost, jobs impacted or the impact to the 84 per cent of the 215 companies impacted. For the brief period I've had the opportunity, as Leader of the Nationals in this place, to question the government, what have you done to assess the impact on my people, my communities and my industries? You have failed to answer very basic questions. You give us nothing to take back to our communities for them to understand the impact of Canberra on their place. It's not a lot to ask.

It's a heavy responsibility that you've been given by the Australian people—the privilege to govern—but you have to govern for all of us. You have to make the tough decisions. That's your mandate. You will do the deals that you will do, but you also need to be able to explain the impact of your decisions to the rest of us who don't live in Fitzroy or inner-city Brisbane, Perth, Sydney or Melbourne. I've been very concerned about the giggles from the Greens when we've asked serious questions about working-class families in our places. They were simple questions, and you were unable to give responses. We clearly won't be supporting the bill, and it's simultaneously disappointing that we couldn't get simple answers to quite simple questions. That was a comment, not a question.

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:00): I note Senator McKenzie's comments. It has been an extended committee stage, and, in the course of the discussion, we have canvassed the consultation arrangements, the analysis that has been undertaken and the level of support that has been provided by a very broad range of business organisations to establish the arrangements for Australian businesses to remain competitive in a world that is decarbonising. Senator McKenzie, I note your views. I can assure you that this government takes very seriously the opportunity to support rural and regional communities. It's something that's important to me and it's important to the government.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:01): I thought I'd briefly correct the record there. The minister mentioned that the world is decarbonising. It's absolutely not. Carbon emissions are increasing and are set to hit record levels because other countries are not doing what we're doing. They're actually investing in their energy security. As I mentioned earlier, the Biden administration is opening up massive amounts of Alaska for oil drilling, and the UK is doing the same in the North Sea. The German Greens party are reopening 24 coal-fired power stations as we speak. Of course, China is building 104 gigawatts of coal-fired power just this year. That's roughly two coal-fired power stations a week. In the time it takes us to debate this bill and pass it through these two chambers, little old China will have built two coal-fired power stations and completely undermined what we're doing here.

Be that as it may, I want to ask some detailed questions, Minister, through you, Chair. In particular, I want to discuss this question of new entrants, which I think is key. In discussions I've been having with concerned companies and investors in the past couple of days since the Labor Party's deal with the Greens, there's been a lot of concern about how new entrants will or won't be treated. There's not a lot of clarity in Minister Bowen's media release. The other day in the Senate, I asked about a specific case, which I might ask again. You've got advisers now, unlike in question time. They might be able to help you out.

I asked about the specific case of the Olive Downs coalmine. I didn't get an answer from Minister Farrell, although I'm not Robinson Crusoe in that regard. Just to explain, Minister, the Olive Downs coalmine is going to be a mine in Central Queensland near Moranbah. It's under construction right now. It has got all of its approvals, of course. There are 500 people working at that mine right now. However, it's not on the safeguard mechanism's list. It's not one of the 215 facilities because it's not an operating mine yet. That will happen. It will go onto that list sometime in the next couple of years. Will it be treated as a new entrant, and, if so, what will its baseline be set at? The investors in this mine have done so on the basis of certain decisions. I don't want to reveal the conversations I've had, but it would be news to them if they were to be considered a new entrant. Will the Olive Downs mine be treated as a new entrant, and what will their baseline be? Can you give any certainty this evening to the 500 people working at that mine about their futures?

Senator McALLI
STER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:04): Thanks, Senator Canavan. As I understand it from the description you've provided, this mine is not currently covered by the safeguard mechanism, because it's not operating; it's under construction. I'm reluctant to make a specific assessment, but in general terms, an entity that commences production and trips the 100,000-tonne threshold would then be considered a safeguard covered facility. New entrants will be required to comply with best practice standards from the first day of operation. Those standards are going to be developed over the course of this year, in consultation with industry.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:05): It's amazing—and, again, I'll refer to my earlier comments—that a government which pretends to be in favour of worker rights and supporting workers can't give any certainty to 500 people employed today. This isn't people in the future; it's not a prospective thing. They're actually working there today. I'm happy to give you the call, Minister, when I conclude, but you have confirmed there for us—correct me if I'm wrong—that this mine will be treated as a new entrant. I think that might be news to the company itself. Clearly, there hasn't been a lot of consultation from the government. They have all their approvals and have been through an EPBC process—they're probably the most assessed mine proposal ever, probably in the world because of the way we go about these things. So I think they'll be quite disappointed at that answer. As I said, there are no guarantees then about the future from the government.

The key thing here will be the way this hard cap works. The way which Mr Bandt describes it is contributing to the uncertainty and confusion out there among investors. It's that big gap between how Mr Bandt describes the 'deal'—the 'sellout', if you like—and how Mr Bowen describes it. Mr Bandt has clear language which is easily interpreted; Mr Bowen has a bunch of bureaucrat-ese which no-one can really navigate. So I will draw you to Mr Bandt's media release, where he says:
A hard cap or ceiling on actual or absolute (gross) emissions, which won't be able to exceed current pollution levels (140 MT per annum), and there will be a decreasing cap over time.
In the government's own position paper, on page 2, it says about the safeguard mechanism:
A reserve would be built into the overall emissions constraint—and applied equally to all facilities—to ensure the 2030 target will be met.
And this is a key thing:
The reserve accounts for higher-than-expected production growth from existing and new facilities and trade exposed baseline adjustments.

My question is this: is the amount of this reserve that the government has flagged now fixed, given the agreement with Mr Bandt and the Greens? That is, will the government not entertain any change to the amount of the reserve between now and 2030? Also, what is the reserve—how much is the reserve, in millions of tonnes of carbon emissions?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:08): Senator, perhaps I can answer that from the other direction. Over the course of the afternoon, I have answered this question in different ways to different senators, but I am engaging with your questions in good faith.
Senator Canavan interjecting—

Senator McALLISTER: The amendments before the chamber establish an overall cap for emissions from covered facilities between now and 2030. That cap is established by applying the 43 per cent reduction threshold to the covered facilities, including some estimates about increases in production activity. That cap is in the legislation and is established as a net cap, so it accounts for the offsets that have been the subject of quite a deal of discussion in recent times. The objects proposed for the act also establish a requirement that the gross emissions decrease over time, and it establishes a metric by which that decrease would be assessed.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:09): I'm still obsessed with this answer, even if you have answered it before. It's just a figure, Minister. All I'm asking is: how much is the reserve? I draw you to Mr Bowen's media release on the deal between the Labor Party and the Greens. The agreement is:
to not exceed the conservatively estimated 1,233 million tonnes of CO2-e to 2030 …

I think that's the figure you were wanting for the overall cap of emissions. My question is not on that figure—a component of the 1,233 will be emissions by existing and, if we ever saw this modelling, possibly some new entrants. In other communications Mr Bowen has mentioned there is a reserve. You've got a specific figure for 1,233, and Minister Bowen has said there is a reserve within that 1,233 to account for new entrants—so there's new investment, which we need in Australia, especially in the energy space. My specific simple question is: how much is that reserve? How much of the 1,233 is set aside for growth from new entrants?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:11): We're not in a position to provide that express reserve at this point. The reason for that is: as a consequence of consultation with industry, part of the things before the chamber that have been discussed over the course of the day are some of the changes around the treatment of the manufacturing sector. We are simply working through those questions.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:11): It's quite remarkable that we're sitting here debating this. I know the government has been mouthing sweet nothings to companies concerned about this issue, saying, 'It's all right, we've got a reserve, it'll be fine, there'll be growth.' I was talking to some people at Aussie's just before about this; they're desperately trying to get information that they can't get from your own minister or the government. They're being told, 'There's a reserve, it's okay.' But you can't even tell us how much is in that reserve. It could be 10, five, 100. Is it enough to even account for or accommodate the Olive Downs mine and/or any others? You won't give me or the Australian people a figure of the reserve. I'll put that aside for now; I might come back to it.

My question now is: what happens if the reserve is empty? What happens if we get other mines—some other senators have spoken of lithium mines, others that exceed the 100,000 tonne threshold—and they come into the system and are given this best practice formula, and they have a positive carbon emission impact, and that uses up some of this reserve? What happens when the reserve gets to zero? Say an Olive Downs project comes along; it's been approved and wants to come along. If the reserve is already at zero at that point, if the reserve is empty, and there's a proposal—it doesn't have to be a coalmine—for another facility to come in, that wants to invest in Australia, and they need to get approval and get credited through the safeguard mechanism, will they have to offset all their emissions? Just to explain this question: if the reserve is at zero, and then a new entrant comes in—if there's no reserve it doesn't matter what the best practice is or what form you want to create to get under your cap, which you're saying is a hard cap, in legislation now, of 1,233 million tonnes—to get under that 1,233 million tonnes they will have to offset all their emissions and be net zero from day one. I'm happy for you to point out where I'm going wrong here with this, but that seems to be the government's proposal because there's no flexibility in the cap.

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:14): Senator Canavan, thanks for the question. I appreciate it's a serious question and I'm happy to assist. You've been speaking about a reserve. It's true that a reserve was incorporated into the calculations to accommodate uncertainty. However, the calculations also included projections about new entrants. The reserve was an additional feature on top of that. The projections around emissions from new entrants are derived from the emissions projections that are produced each year by the department, which I think you would be familiar with.

Nonetheless, you asked what would happen in the circumstances where the minister was notified that there was a new approval for a new facility of any kind and it would be likely that the fixed caps would not be able to be met, that the objects of the act were not able to be met. The consequence of that circumstance would be for the minister to undertake consultation about the rules as a whole. It would not be for the minister to engage or impose requirements on a particular project. I hope that assists.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:15): I'll come back to that. There are a lot of questions from that answer. I do appreciate it. It helps a lot. I just go back to the reserve figure. I thought I remembered this and have brought it up. On 7 March there was an article on the ABC website titled 'Chris Bowen challenges parliament to accept safeguard mechanism, or risk losing chance to cut emissions'. Later on in the article Mr Bowen is quoted as saying:
We've factored in a reserve of 17 million tonnes to cater for what we need.
Is Mr Bowen right? Is the reserve 17 million tonnes?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:16): As I indicated to you in my earlier answer, as a consequence of the consultations that have been taking place since the publication in January of the draft rules, we are proposing a different treatment of the manufacturing sector and that has some consequences for the reserve, and we're working through that.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:16): So the reserve is a moving feast at the moment? This doesn't add up. Something doesn't add up here. We've got a hard cap, we've got a reserve and we've got a growth factor as well for new entrants. They all have to add up to 1,233 million tonnes, because you're saying that that's the cap in the legislation. Now you're saying, 'No, we've changed the 17 million tonnes.' Mr Bowen was happy to tell the ABC that the reserve was 17 million tonnes. You must have a figure right now because your cap is 1,233 million tonnes. What is the figure of the reserve tonight? Has it changed from the 17 million tonnes? Please tell us. Mr Bowen already told the public this, so there's no public interest immunity here and no cabinet issues. He told the ABC what the reserve was. What is the reserve in your calculations tonight? You must have the spreadsheet back there that adds up to 1,233 million tonnes. What is the figure for the reserve?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:17): Senator Canavan, I've explained to you that the reserve also includes the concessional arrangements that are put in place for some of the trade-exposed industries. I've also explained to you that there is a proposal to shift that as a consequence of consultation with the manufacturing sector. You would expect our government to take a keen interest in representations from the manufacturing sector. We've made it clear that, under certain circumstances, the baseline decline expected of some manufacturing entities may be less than would otherwise have been under the proposal circulated in January, and we're working through the consequences of that in the way that you've requested.

Senator CANAVAN (Queensland) (21:18): I think it's very germane at this point to just point out that the government's reserve—and we haven't heard otherwise—may be shifted a bit from 17 million tonnes, but it seems like as good a figure as any. Mr Bowen has confirmed that in the media. Even if there has been a shift, it is probably a few million tonnes here or there. That is 17 million tonnes of the 1,233 million tonnes that's the overall cap for the next seven years. That's our carbon budget we're stuck to for manufacturing, for mining and for transport in this country. We can't do more than that. This is a cap on economic growth. Let's be clear what the government has confirmed tonight: it's a cap on Australia's economic prosperity, it's a cap on our economic growth and it's a cap on our ability to make things and manufacture things in this country. We can't exceed this cap. They're going to put it in law. It's stuck.

Okay, to give the government their due, they have put a reserve in it. They have been very generous and put a reserve to account for some growth. Well, 17 million tonnes out of 1,233 million tonnes—guess what that works out to? 1.3 per cent. We can grow 1.3 per cent over the next seven years. How good is that! You think we'd like our economic growth to be somewhere around three or four. You'd like that to be the case. You'd hope and pray that we can offer the Australian people increasing real wages and living standards over time. Keep in mind that, if we don't grow as an economy, your real wages won't go up, your living standards won't go up, things will get more expensive and you won't get paid more.

What the government is saying is that now the only thing you can expect is a 1.3 per cent increase in your living standards over seven years—seven years! This was a mob that came to power by saying they're going to make your life easier, they're going to cut power prices and they're going to increase real wages. And here tonight they're putting in a cap on your living standards, a cap on what you can afford. We've had that confirmed tonight by the minister, unless she can say otherwise. Unless she can tell us what the other figure is here, it is 17 million tonnes out of 1.2 billion, and that's 1.3 per cent over seven years. That's not 1.3 per cent a year, by the way; it's 1.3 per cent for seven years. So let's just work that out. It's 1.3 per cent over seven years, so the growth per year is a whole 0.18 per cent. Every year you can grow and your life can get better by 0.18 per cent. So, if you're earning 100 grand at the moment, you can thank your lucky stars and you will get a pay increase of—let me work this out. I don't use this calculator very often. I should be able to do this in my head, but I'm getting old! You'll get a pay increase of $18. You can look forward, under this hard cap, to an $18 a year pay increase! Don't spend it all at once! That's my advice. It's just $18. That's what they're doing to us. It's a hard cap on our economic growth, and that's what they've just admitted here in this place.

I want to go back, though. Minister, one of the answers you gave me was quite revealing. You mentioned that we've got a reserve, which you won't and can't tell us about. Mr Bowen could tell the ABC how much the reserve is, but he can't tell a parliament—but it's about 17 million tonnes. You also mentioned that you've got a growth factor in there for new entrants. You're already projecting some new entrants over the next seven years. My question is: how much is that? You've obviously done that work. You've admitted you've done the calculations. Under that 1,233 million tonne cap, how much, in your calculations, have you factored in for emissions from new entrants until 2030?

Senator McALLISTER (New South Wales—Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy) (21:23): The projections that are generated to 2030 include new entrants but also growth in existing production. The total volume, without an intervention, to 2030 is 1,017 megatonnes. Senators, we are scheduled to sit again tomorrow and deal with this same matter. Accordingly, I move:
That the committee report progress and ask leave to sit again.

The C
HAIR: The question before the chair is that the committee report progress.
Senator WONG (South Australia—Minister for Foreign Affairs and Leader of the Government in the Senate) (21:31): I move:
That the committee have leave to sit again on the next day of sitting.
And I move:
That the question be now put.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the question be put.
The PRESIDENT (21:39): The question is that the motion as moved by Senator Wong that the committee have leave to sit again on the next day of sitting be agreed to.
Question agreed to.
ADJOURNMENT
Senator WONG: I move:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
The PRESIDENT: The question is that the motion as moved by Senator Wong be agreed to.
